{"step_by_step_thinking": "Carey Coombs murmur is a short, mid-diastolic rumble best heard at the apex. It is associated with mitral valvulitis due to acute rheumatic fever. It is often associated with an S3 gallop rhythm. It can be distinguished from the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis by the absence of an opening snap before the murmur. Therefore, the false statement about Carey Coombs murmur is that it is a delayed diastole murmur.", "answer_choice": "A"}
